--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Derek James <blue5432@y...> wrote:

> What were you in California for?  A conference?
> 

No actually I visited a couple universities and gave talks there.

> 
> I think the basic approach Philip and I are going to
> take is to calculate some sort of percentage
> difference between chromosomes for usage as a
> speciation threshold.  If we find that our populations
> are either underspeciation or overspeciating, then
> we'll modify the threshold to be dynamic.
> 

When will you calculate this difference?  During evolution
itself?  Or some kind of preprocessing?  

> 
> I'm not sure either.  Intuitively, I'd be inclined to
> say that adding a node to a three-node network, in
> general, has a more profound effect on its behavior
> than adding a node to a 500-node network.  
> 
> After all, one of the inherent features of distributed
> computing approaches like neural networks is their
> robustness.  A few thousand brain cells die off here
> or there, a chunk of the mouse's brain is cut out, but
> overall function isn't impacted significantly.  And I
> would think that the robustness of the network would
> only increase as the size of the network increased,
> and more redundancy and distribution become features
> of the system.
>  

Yes true I agree.  But there is a number under which 
I think realtive size is less important.  I just don't
know what that number is.

> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Derek James"
> > <blue5432@y...> wrote:
> So the speciation mechanism for an
> > indirect encoding 
> > > scheme would probably need to base speciation on
> > phenotype.
> > 
> > I strongly disagree with this.  Species in biology
> > are organisms that
> > share genetic history.  Those organisms in separate
> > species share less
> > genetic history.  And the history is *genetic* and
> > not phenotypic- and
> > genetic history is exactly what historical markings
> > measure.  If you
> > give up on that, you are left with massive analytic
> > problem of
> > comparing phenotypic morphologies and
> > functionalities that are wildly
> > complex.  But why do that when we know genetic
> > history?
> 
> Hmm...I honestly hadn't thought about this much when I
> answered Colin's point.  I guess I was thinking about
> sex in the real world, and the fact that what
> determines whether two organisms can successfully mate
> is their phenotype, rather than their genotype (e.g.,
> a neutered dog is genetically compatible with a
> fertile one of the opposite sex, but its phenotypic,
> um, limitations, keep it from mating).
> 
> That is, things that happen to phenotypes in their
> environment can lead to inabilities to actually mate. 
> But maybe carrying this level of literalness into the
> GA domain is a bit too much.
> 

Yes, and I'm not really sure you can say it's their phenotype
which really keeps it from mating.  After all, many animals
*could* mate physically, but they choose not to.  I'm not saying 
they would have viable offspring, but they could at least
give it a try.  So it's more a "decision" they make not to 
mate.  (I realize of course the decision-making apparatus is also
part of the phenotype.) But the NN's we are evolving right now are 
far from being capable of "deciding" on their own whom to mate with,
so something has to make the decision for them.

> But I don't know.  Basically, if you use an indirect
> encoding scheme, the resultant organism is a
> combination of genetic determinism and influences from
> the environment.  If you base their compatibility
> solely on their genetic similarities, aren't you
> ignoring the environmental influences on the
> development of an organism?  And isn't how an
> indirectly-encoded phenotype develops and performs
> important to determining its fitness and the extent to
> which it should reproduce?
> 

You cannot mate two phenotypes unless you have a direct encoding. 
When people mate, it's their DNA that's recombining not their bodies.
I'm not sure where environmental influence comes into play.
If the DNA are not compatible, they won't produce an offspring
regardless of the environment.  I suppose if their DNA is compatible
there could still be some kind of physical injury or pathology in
one of the organisms preventing mating, but this hardly seems
important for artificial evolution.  So I don't think the environment
is relevant here.  

I agree that how something develops contributes to its fitness
and the extent to which it should reproduce.  But the genome is what
determines how it should develop!  And also, fitness is not the same
as compatibility.  All humans (more or less) are compatible for
mating, whether the least intelligent and most physically unfit, or
the geniuses with olympic potential.  They are all the same species.
DNA doesn't care who's more fit when the mating happens.

> > I also disagree with the idea that changing a gene
> > in indirect
> > encoding can have a huge impact on phenotype.  I
> > think this is only
> > true in a *bad* indirect encoding.  In a good
> > indirect encoding, such
> > as DNA, there is canalization, which means that it's
> > difficult to get
> > massive perturbations in phenotype from small
> > changes in genotype.  
> 
> Hmm...this is interesting.  How does this work in
> nature?  I'm thinking, for example, of a millipede. 
> Is it the case with the legs of a millipede that there
> is a strand of DNA that encodes for a single leg, that
> is then looped through to create all of the
> millipede's legs?  If so, then wouldn't a mutation
> that affects one leg then have a profound effect on
> the organism as a whole?
> 

It would have an impact on all the legs, but the point is
it would be a *small* impact.  It's not like a single
amino acid mutation is going to cause the millipede to suddenly
grow feet, or lose its legs entirely for that matter.  
Single gene mutations will tend to have very small incremental
effects on morphology.

Here's the important point:  Can you imagine a single amino acid
mutation in a human that actually creates a new species!?  
Sure, there may be a few critical sections of DNA where getting
something wrong actually hurts fitness, but that doesn't mean
the offspring is no longer human.  Human (and other animal)
development is canalized against such extreme kinds of change.

In contrast, if you look at an indirect encoding like L-systems
for example, changing a single character in the string can
have massive impact, creating *unrecognizable* offspring.  I think
that's a pretty good sign that L-systems are not canalized like
DNA, and that we have to develop better encodings.

> I don't claim to know much about this subject.  How is
> fault tolerance for indirect encoding handled by
> biological organisms?  You refer to this as
> "canalization", and I do remember you talking about
> this in the artificial embryogeny paper, but I'm not
> sure I understand the concept well.
> 

As you mentioned, (for other people in the group if they
are interested) take a look at the Canalization section 
(section 3.4) of our Taxonomy paper to see the details.
I mentioned 3 things in that paper that can lead to canalization:
Stochasticity, Resource Allocation, and Overproduction.  
There are probably more.  Note most indirect encodings today
have none of these features and display no sign of canalization.
Evolution also plays a role over the long term: it will 
canalize its forms simply because that makes them more like to
produce viable offspring.   Vageuly speaking, what happens is that 
development develops a kind of redundancy, in which if one path
is shifted, another one can pick up the slack.  

> > In
> > other words, the system is more or less robust to
> > change on the macro
> > level.  It is important not to confuse current
> > primitive indirect
> > encodings with the potentially powerful indirect
> > encodings we will
> > ultimately use.  An encoding where flipping a bit
> > can result in an
> > unrecognizable phenotypic mutant is terribly
> > brittle, and should not
> > be the basis of our intuitions about
> > complexification or speciation.
> 
> Again, I'm wondering about how biological organisms
> attain this robustness.  Surely in the case of
> structures (such as blood cells) that are produced
> millions of times over, there is encoding for a single
> blood cell.  And if a mutation occurs in that genetic
> material, how is it not going to result in massive
> perturbations in the phenotype?
> 

But are you suggesting that the new phenotypes would no
longer be human?  Because remember we are talking about
speciation here.  And anyway, things aren't as simple
as a one-to-one mapping in an indirect encoding, so a mutation
in the code itself does not necessarily lead to an unrecognizable
blood cell.  Perhaps slightly altered, but it may be better,
it may be worse, and it is likely not something entirely novel.
Also canalization means different parts of the system can
pick up slack when other parts are altered.  So even if the
blood cell type alters slightly, the parts the blood cells interact
with may themselves be flexible in those interactions, such that
they can deal with a slightly altered counterpart.  It's as if your
house keys could remold themselves slightly on their own.  Then if
I changed the locks on your doors, your keys would still work as
long as the change wasn't too dramatic and still bore some resemblance
to the earlier configuration.

I think the really important point here though is that you aren't
going to get something that isn't human by changing a single gene.
And that's what matters for speciation: small changes in the genotypes
don't lead to new species.  

Mainly your examples have been about *damage* to the phenotype.  And
consider that a damaged phenotypes is not a new species at all, but
rather just a weaker version of the same.  Try to imagine a
non-damaging small genetic mutation that actually can lead immediately
to an entirely new species.  To me it's inconceivable; it is clear
that evolution requires the accumulation of many many mutations over
many generations to get an entirely new character.

> > I do agree, it is still aquestion whether N should
> > be used or not in
> > any encoding, whether direct or indirect.  I believe
> > I've heard that
> > monkeys have 99% of the genetic history as humans. 
> > Assuming this is
> > true, if we were normalizing for genome size, I
> > think we'd conclude
> > that monkeys and people were in the same species!
> 
> Well, you probably could, with a little tweaking, get
> a viable embryo that's a result of chimp and human DNA
> (this may not be far off in the future).  I think this
> will tend to blur the line of what a true biological
> species is (which is already somewhat fuzzy).
> 

I think this just emphasizes the fact that speciation is
not an exact science and just needs to be "good enough."
Maybe chimps could mate with people, but the fact that they
don't isn't devastating.  So I think that a lot of our
concern is not going to have massive impact.  It's not
exactly "where you draw the line" that matters, but that
you do draw it somewhere and with some regularity.

> > The issue behind the best way to use N (perhaps some
> > nonlinear
> > formula), if at all, is certainly an open question. 
> > But I don't think
> > there is any future in comparing phenotypes instead
> > of genotypes.
> 
> I'm not entirely sold, but I'll admit that it is a
> very interesting question. :)
> 

Here my big concern:  If you really propose to compare
phenotypes for speciation, you are back to the competing
conventions problem with different topologies 
that NEAT solves.  We are literally back at square one.
Can you imagine the kind of graph theory analysis necessary
to establish that two morphologies are the same species?
It isn't even about macro-level similarity.  A human with
no arms or legs is still human.  It would be mind boggling
to come up with a formula that captures the intrinsic nature
of "human-ness" from the phenotype.  On the other hand, the
genotype is completely sufficient: we all share a certain level
of genetic similarity.  And with historical marking that
level is wholly apparent.  So I don't want to go down the
wrong path here back to the problems we started with.

Well, I really went on a long time here, but hopefully it helps
clarify my position and contributes to people's thoughts on
the matter, which I think will be important in the future.

ken
